report_title: Office Furniture Manufacturing in the US
executive_summary: Office furniture manufacturing has endured significant volatility, with revenue declining over the years leading up to 2024. Macroeconomic instability in recent years – including spiking unemployment, jumping interest rates, rising office rental vacancies and declining value of private nonresidential construction – have contributed to weaker demand for new office furniture. Similarly, work-from-home and hybrid working trends have harmed demand for domestic producers. Basic, low-cost, mass-produced furniture items endure heightened competition from more affordable imports, particularly those from China. At the same time, exports have declined amid the recent appreciation of the US dollar. These trends have caused revenue to weaken at an estimated CAGR of 2.6% to $29.2 billion, including a minor gain of 0.1% that year alone.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Cyclical demand and trends continue to be a factor
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Office furniture sales are directly tied to cyclical demand from downstream businesses. As businesses wear through old furniture, these buyers have to buy new pieces to replace existing ones, supporting sales.
Like many other manufacturing industries, foreign producers pose a significant threat to domestic manufacturers, satisfying more than 20.0% of domestic demand.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Office rental vacancy is set to stagnate
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Office rental vacancies are set to begin falling over the coming years as macroeconomic conditions improve, and businesses continue with return-to-office mandates. However, this recovery is set to be slow, contributing to small revenue gains over the coming years.

The dollar is set to depreciate over the coming years as international economic and political factors improve. A weaker dollar makes domestically-produced furniture comparatively more affordable and US producers more competitive globally, supporting revenue growth.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Long term drivers of demand will continue
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Businesses' need to regularly replace and refresh old furniture will continue to be a key source of growth for demand for new office furniture.

industry_definition: Operators in the Office Furniture Manufacturing industry manufacture a wide range of office furniture, including bookcases, cabinets, chairs, desks and filing cabinets. This industry also manufactures office and store fixtures, such as cafeteria countertops (except kitchen and bathroom), furniture parts and partitions. Furniture may be ordered predesigned or customized, and may be sold assembled or unassembled.
key_trends: Most of the industry is comprised of many small manufacturers.
These players sell niche products or generic furniture that competes with imports, preventing them from capturing a large share of the market.
Imported products threaten domestic manufacturers. Foreign producers benefit from lower production costs, enabling them to undercut domestic prices.
Charge lower prices and intensify price-based competition
A recovering nonresidential sector has kickstarted revenue growth
Improving macroeconomic conditions, including rising corporate profit and lower unemployment, creates growth opportunities
The economic recovery is slowly supporting new furniture sales
Nonresidential construction is picking up, and lowering unemployment rates is helping, but these gains have yet to offset pandemic-related losses
A weakening dollar will make US furniture more competitive
Steelcase is committed to tackling climate change with concrete environmental goals
The economic recovery is driving revenue growth
Office furniture manufacturers must adhere to various regulations
Rising operating costs are hurting profit
Supply chain issues have increased purchase costs
The Southwest's large population generates steady demand for furniture
California and New York's business hubs need a lot of office furniture
Custom office furniture offers a silver lining for manufacturers
Businesses are buying more office furniture directly from producers

market_segmentation.segment_description: This segment accounts for the businesses that rely on office furniture for internal use and daily operations, including large office buildings and smaller, local storefront offices.
This segment includes retailers who purchase office furniture for resale. The furniture these businesses buy for end-use is included in the business end users segment.
This segment includes independent wholesalers who buy directly from factories for distribution. These wholesalers often have contacts and distribution infrastructure that manufacturers can lack.
This segment accounts for demand from other markets, including government agencies and a wide variety of other markets that generate some demand for office furniture.
This segment accounts for demand from other markets, including government agencies and a wide variety of other markets that generate some demand for office furniture.

products_and_services.product_description: This segment includes custom display fixtures and shelving units, as well as paneling, architectural woodwork and reception counters. Demand for custom office fixtures has grown in part because downstream companies seek interiors that align with their organization needs and business processes.

This segment includes moveable furniture such as desks, related accessories and chairs. These products are subject to trends, including the increasing popularity of ergonomic furniture and standing desks, which can drive sales.

This segment includes moveable furniture such as desks, related accessories and chairs. These products are subject to trends, including the increasing popularity of ergonomic furniture and standing desks, which can drive sales.
This segment includes storage units (which includes file cabinets of various sizes and materials), tables and storage racks and accessories.
This segment accounts for permanent fixtures, such as cabinets, bookcases and cubicles, which subdivide offices into personal workspaces and are commonly sold prefabricated.

tier_1_suppliers: Iron & Steel Manufacturing in the US
Wood Paneling Manufacturing in the US
tier_2_suppliers: Electric Power Transmission in the US
Industrial Machinery & Equipment Wholesaling in the US
tier_1_buyers: Office Supply Stores in the US
Finance and Insurance in the US
Professional, Scientific and Technical Services in the US
tier_2_buyers: Warehouse Clubs & Supercenters in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Corporate profit plays a crucial role in determining a company's spending on new office furniture. When corporate profit is higher, businesses are more inclined to invest in new furniture. On the other hand, weakened corporate profit pushes companies to lower spending and postpone non-essential purchases, adversely affecting office furniture sales.

international_trade_points.trade_title: China Leads in Office Furniture Imports
international_trade_points.trade_description: China has consistently been the leading source of office furniture imports as lax labor and environmental regulations lower operating costs and allow foreign producers to charge lower prices, appealing to companies aiming to keep purchase costs low.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Imports Continue to Pose a Threat
international_trade_points.trade_description: The recent appreciation of the US dollar has allowed competition from office furniture imports to remain a significant threat.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Canada and Mexico are the Leading Destinations for Office Furniture Exports
international_trade_points.trade_description: Most domestic office furniture exports go to Canada and Mexico, largely due to the geographic proximity. Transporting office furniture over longer distances internationally can be inefficient and expensive, preventing exports from accounting for a significant share of revenue.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Exports Grow Slightly as a Share of Revenue
international_trade_points.trade_description: Exports have grown slightly as a share of revenue because of the growing popularity of high-quality domestic furniture, particularly among Mexican buyers. However, unstable global macroeconomic conditions, including elevated inflation and unstable construction activity, have prevented exports from growing faster.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast region has the highest percentage of establishments at 29.1%, while its population percentage is 21.8%.
The Great Lakes region has 18.5% of establishments and 15.1% of the population.
The West region has 14.2% of establishments but a higher 23.5% of the population.
The Mid-Atlantic region has 12.3% of establishments and 13.4% of the population.

The Southwest is home to various population-dense centers. Highly populated cities offer consistent demand for furniture and provide a larger labor pool for manufacturers. The region's proximity to export markets further supports the strategic location of these industry hubs.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Office furniture manufacturers use materials that contain hazardous chemicals subject to a wide range of federal, state and local laws and regulations relating to worker health and safety, and the emission, discharge, storage, treatment and disposal of hazardous materials.

U.S. patent and trademark laws ensure the protection of intellectual property rights. These regulations govern innovations in manufacturing processes and custom furniture designs, which are essential for companies to distinguish themselves from competitors.

regulations_points.regulation_title: California Flammability Standard for Upholstered Furniture
regulations_points.regulation_description: Upholstered furniture is commonly stuffed with polyurethane, which is known to accelerate residential fires and increase the risk of severe injury or death. In 1975, California required such furniture to undergo testing to ensure it could withstand exposure to an open flame without spreading the fire.

The Lacey Act is a federal law in the United States prohibiting the trade of wildlife, fish and plants illegally obtained, transported or sold. The law also makes importing plant or animal species that violate a foreign country's laws illegal. The law requires documentation of imported lumber to ensure it was not harvested illegally.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The industry is in a mature life cycle stage.
The level of industry assistance is low and steady.
The capital intensity level is low, decreasing barriers.
The concentration level is low, decreasing barriers.
Office furniture manufacturers don't encounter many legal barriers, but must comply with standard manufacturing regulations including strict environmental standards.
Entering the industry comes with significant expenses like establishing a manufacturing facility, procuring materials, and establishing supply chain relationships which is a financial burden.
Differentiation poses challenges due to many players, often foreign-based, offering lower-priced products, making it tough for new entrants to stand out.
Labor costs are a barrier as manufacturers rely on a skilled workforce that increases operating costs, giving manufacturers with lower labor expenses a competitive advantage.

basis_points.basis_description: Most of the industry is comprised of many small manufacturers that sell niche products or generic furniture that competes with imports, preventing them from capturing a large share of the market.
Imported products threaten domestic manufacturers as foreign producers benefit from lower production costs, enabling them to charge lower prices and intensify price-based competition.

concentration_points.concentration_description: There are a few larger name brands like Steelcase, Millerknoll and HNI that are able to gain larger market shares by producing furniture under known brand names.
While there are a few larger manufacturers, most industry revenue comes from small manufacturers serving local markets, keeping concentration moderate overall.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Purchase Costs Rise Amid Input Price Volatility
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchase costs account for the largest expense for furniture producers. Input materials used in office furniture production include hardwood, plywood, veneers, steel, glass, plastic, rubber and glue.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: As Consumer Favor Custom Pieces, Wage Expenses Grow
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Furniture manufacturers rely heavily on skilled workers because the largest product segment is custom furniture pieces.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Office Furniture Revenue Moves With The Overall Business Cycle
volatility_points.volatility_description: Office furniture revenue is closely tied to the overall business cycle. During economic downturns, companies cut back on investments in new furniture, directly impacting the industry's sales.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Economic Instability Drives Furniture Sector Volatility
volatility_points.volatility_description: The 2020 pandemic negatively impacted nonresidential construction, as work-from-home trends and rising unemployment drove office vacancy rates higher. This contributed to the significant volatility faced by office furniture manufacturers.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Increased Custom Work Has Shifted Product Lines
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Custom work is on the rise as companies aim to strengthen their brand identity. These products stand out in the market due to their service-heavy approach.

FAQs.question: Are your company's sales heavily dependent on the health of the US economy?
FAQs.answer: Sales are strongest when businesses are expanding, and are therefore highly cyclical.

FAQs.question: How is your company impacted by rising imports from abroad?
FAQs.answer: Companies that create stock furniture are vulnerable to import competition, while companies that perform custom work are largely immune.

FAQs.question: Has your company been exposed to volatile input prices over the past few years?
FAQs.answer: The price of steel has been volatile, partly due to tariffs implemented on imported steel. Lumber and metal prices often fluctuate based on demand and other trade conditions. As a result, furniture manufacturers are susceptible to volatile input prices.

FAQs.question: Has your company located in proximity to its key downstream distributors to reduce shipping costs?
FAQs.answer: The importance of location varies depending on a company's product focus, with custom interior businesses requiring more proximity to commercial centers.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to reduce wage costs by automating operations over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: As the industry has placed a greater emphasis on customization, it hasn't been able to automate the manufacturing process, driving wage costs higher.

FAQs.question: How does your company invest in technology, such as 3D printing, to establish a competitive edge over your competitors?
FAQs.answer: Any technology that reduces costs can become a major advantage, particularly among stock furniture producers that face high price competition.

FAQs.question: How does your company stay ahead of regulations?
FAQs.answer: The industry is not heavily regulated. Manufacturers' exposure is largely determined by the extent of local environmental regulations and having to ensure the products meet quality standards.

FAQs.question: What effect have international tariffs had on your ability to import and export products?
FAQs.answer: Export sales are not significant, but could be hurt as recent US policy changes lead to retaliatory trade barriers erected by other countries.

FAQs.question: How is your company impacted by the seasonality of cash flow?
FAQs.answer: Much furniture is closely tied to new construction activity, which is fairly seasonal in many regions.

FAQs.question: What percentage of your company's customers renew their contracts?
FAQs.answer: Furniture items are often one-time purchases, but contracts may be available with large corporations or retail chains that have recurring needs for new furniture.

FAQs.question: Do you maintain good relationships with key suppliers? Do you have a steady list of contracts/suppliers?
FAQs.answer: Having established links with key suppliers enables a steady flow of key inputs and price locks, which may provide cost savings for bulk purchases. Manufacturers without strong relationships with suppliers are susceptible to fluctuations in input prices, driving operating costs higher.

FAQs.question: How do you keep up to date with office furniture trends?
FAQs.answer: Tastes and preferences, as they relate to office furniture and the use of office space, change regularly. To remain competitive, the furniture produced should reflect the current trends favored by consumers.

FAQs.question: What training process do your employees undergo? Are your employees high-skilled workers?
FAQs.answer: A highly trained workforce is essential for office furniture manufacturers, as many of the goods produced in the industry are custom-made pieces that require quality workmanship.

FAQs.question: How have fluctuations in the value of the US dollar affected demand for your products? How do you plan to mitigate the threat of imports?
FAQs.answer: As the value of the dollar declines, it leads to lower relative export prices and higher import prices, benefiting industry revenue. A strong US dollar, on the other hand, negatively impacts demand for domestically produced furniture, harming demand for US manufacturers. Since downstream buyers are often price-conscious, they are more likely to purchase affordable pieces.

FAQs.question: How do you anticipate corporate profit might impact your company's sales projections?
FAQs.answer: Corporate profit determines a company's available budget for office furniture and other related purchases. When earnings are high, companies are more likely to purchase new furniture.

FAQs.question: Do you track the national unemployment rate? How has an increasing unemployment rate decreased demand for your company's products?
FAQs.answer: When unemployment is high, demand for new furniture declines as office vacancies rise and fewer employees are hired. A lower unemployment rate often translates to higher demand for commercial real estate, creating a need for office furniture.
